sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying inductor
message_1: A current-carrying inductor with 100 turns and a radius of 5 cm has a current of 2A flowing through it. Calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 10 cm from the center of the inductor.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 10 cm from the center of the inductor, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop of wire, also known as the Biot-Savart Law. The formula is:

B = (μ₀ * I * N * r²) / (2 * (r² + x²)^(3/2))

where:
B is the magnetic field,
μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A),
I is the current (2 A),
N is the number of turns (100),
r is the radius of the inductor (0.05 m),
x is the distance from the center of the inductor (0.1 m).

Plugging in the values, we get:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 100 * (0.05 m)²) / (2 * ((0.05 m)² + (0.1 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 100 * 0.0025 m²) / ((0.0025 m² + 0.01 m²)^(3/2))

B = (2π × 10^(-5) Tm/A) / (0.0125 m²)^(3/2)

B = (2π × 10^(-5) Tm/A) / (0.0125 m²)^(3/2)

B ≈ 1.13 × 10^(-5) T

So, the magnetic field at a distance of 10 cm from the center of the inductor is approximately 1.13 × 10^(-5) T (Tesla).
